occurrences.line_text: But ere she could him reach, the sinfull sowle
So she them seeing past the reach of eare,
Till I was throughly past the perill of his reach.
These towring rocks, which reach vnto the skie,
Ill can he rule the great, that cannot reach the small.
Their sound did reach vnto the heauens hight.
Sith shady dampe had dimd the heauens reach,
For all that euer came within his reach,
That one sure stroke he might vnto him reach,
Then vp arose a person of deepe reach,
Of armes, that if I yet him nigh may reach,
She it reuiues and new occasion reaches:
And at that instant reaching forth his sweard
That nothing may escape her reaching might,
Therefore I read beware. Fly fly (quoth then
(Let none them read) thereof did verses frame,
And fortunes tell, and read in louing bookes,
And read her sorrow in her count'nance sad;
But all in vaine: for he has read his end
Full hard it is (quoth he) to read aright
That none could read, except she did them teach,
I read the man, that euer would deceaue
And read, who hath ye wrought this shamefull plight.
But read how art thou nam'd, and of what kin.
Of curtesie to me the cause a read,
I read thee rash, and heedlesse of thy selfe,
All otherwise (said he) I riches read,
Abandone soone, I read, the caitiue spoile
And to him said, Now felon sure I read,
But read what wicked hand hath robbed mee
Sir knight, mote I of you this curt'sie read,
Such life ye read, and vertue in vaine shew,
To read those bookes; who gladly graunted their desire.
But Guyon all this while his booke did read,
To read, what manner musicke that mote bee:
Therefore a read Sir, if thou haue a loue.
And read, where I that faytour false may find.
Ne soothlich is it easie for to read,
But if that loue it be, as sure I read
Or whence it sprong, I cannot read aright:
But this I read, that but if remedee
But read (said Glauce) thou Magitian
Ah read, (quoth Britomart) how is she hight?
But when I read, how stout Debora strake
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
But can ye read Sir, how I may her find, or where.
As ye may elsewhere read that ruefull history.
But read, thou Squyre of Dames, what vow is this,
Ah (said she) father, I note read aright,
And freely read, what wicked felon so
Of persons flockt, whose names is hard to read:
A read thou Squire, that I the man may learne,
The signes of anguish one mote plainely read,
Which that same knight, whom by his launce I read,
But read to me, by what deuise or wit,
Of two full hard to read the harder theft.
The read thereof for guerdon of my paine,
Nor read the saluage cũtreis, thorough which they pace.
Nought could she read the roote of his disease,
Now lesse she feared that same fatall read,
Read therefore who it is, which this hath wrought,
That dare discourse of so diuine a read,
But looke who does dissent from this my read,
In cyphers strange, that few could rightly read,
Or with her owne good will, I cannot read aright.
Bit him behind, that long the marke was to be read.
Well may I certes such an one thee read,
To whose wise read she hearkning, sent me streight
That rather needes wise read and discipline,
And euery body two, and two she foure did read.
But read thou shepheard, read what destiny,
But read thou shepheard, read what destiny,
That she may hearke to loue, and reade this lesson often.
But reade you Sir, sith ye my name haue hight,
Her rather reade his meaning, then him selfe it spake.
Whose names and natures I note readen well;
Who wonders not, that reades so wonderous worke?
Miraculous may seeme to him, that reades
That readie entrance was not at his call:
That twise he reeled, readie twise to fall;
Through mirkesome aire her readie way she makes.
Amendment readie still at hand did wayt,
And shoke his scales to battell readie drest;
And did himselfe to battell readie dight;
And in the rest his readie speare did sticke;
They bene ymet, both readie to affrap,
And yield him readie passage to that other part.
Readie to drowne himselfe for fell despight.
So readie dight, fierce battaile to assay,
And his mischieuous bow full readie bent,
Ne hedge ne ditch his readie passage brake,
Where many Groomes and Squiers readie were,
Her snowy brest was bare to readie spoyle
In captiue bandes, which there they readie found:
They both vprose and tooke their readie way
But forward rode, and kept her readie way
Them yielded readie passage, and their rage surceast.
Were hard behind, her readie to arrest:
With greedy iawes her readie for to teare;
Of readie entrance, which ought euermore
So readie rype to ill, ill wemens counsels bee.
And readie seeing him with her to fly,
They to his succour ran with readie ayd:
Returned readie newes, that those same weare
And there arresting, readie way did yield,
Who him affronting soone to fight was readie prest.
And readie were new battell to darraine.
They passing forth kept on their readie way,
Had not the noble Prince his readie stroke represt.
The royall child with readie quicke foresight,
Who thereto did with readie will consent,
And to his fortunes helpe make readie way?
And readie to deserue, what grace I found.
The Briton Prince him readie did awayte,
So fast away, that ere his readie speare
And all his armours readie dight that day,
When he was readie to his steede to mount
Into his shield it readie passage found,
To weete if shipping readie he mote there descry.
A ship all readie (as good fortune fell)
Whereas they readie found them to repell,
And cast his shield about, to be in readie plight.
Whom when her Host saw readie to depart,
Tho when as all things readie were aright,
Readie to launce her brest, and let out loued life.
And supper readie dight, they to it fell
Was readie oft his owne hart to deuoure,
T'inquire for slaues; where being readie met
And his owne flesh he readie was to teare:
The readie way vnto that theeuish wonne,
Where all the rest for him did readie stay,
That readily they shut and open might.
Of which her selfe auising readily,
As she had learned readily by rote.
The rest my selfe too readily can spell.
And bad her all things put in readinesse anon.
So stood they both in readinesse thereby,
In readinesse, forth to the Towne-gate went;
Who reading it with inward loathfulnesse,
Redoubted battaile ready to darrayne,
But got his ready steed, and fast away gan ride.
From thence to heauen she teacheth him the ready path.
That nothing might his ready passage stay:
And euer ready for your foeman fell.
He that braue steed there finding ready dight,
To melt the golden metall, ready to be tride.
And were enraunged ready, still for fight.
And ready dight with drapets festiuall,
Where them awaited ready at the ford
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
To speake a while, ne ready answere make,
Tho to their ready Steeds they clombe full light,
His ready wound with better salues new drest;
The Monster ready on the pray to sease,
And forth issewd, as on the ready flore
One in bright armes, with ready speare in rest,
Shewing him selfe all ready for the field.
And as it fell, his steed he ready found.
Till I thereto had all things ready dight.
With bow in hand, and arrowes ready bent,
And euer in her bow she ready shewed
Euen as he ready was there to haue entred,
With ready hand it to haue reft away.
Attended duely, ready to obay;
But thitherward forthright his ready way did make.
Where on the Bridge he ready armed saw
Together ran with ready speares in rest.
With weapons in their hands, as ready for to fight.
As ready for the gallow tree prepard:
Where was a rich Pauilion ready pight,
So forth she rode vppon her ready way,
Two Knights, all armed ready for to fight,
And in his hand his thresher ready keight.
Was to the battell whilome ready dight.
Did forth issue, all ready for the fight:
In stead of whom finding there ready prest
He at him ran, with ready speare in rest:
Her ready to assaile, was greatly queld,
And long restrayned of his ready course;
That from the battlements she ready seem'd to fall.
With wounds, is ready to forgo the ghost:
Besides a thousand more, which ready bee
When he the beast saw ready now to rend
With Vnaes foe, that all her realme did pray.
Thy name Ã´ soueraine Queene, thy realme and race,
Thus Brute this Realme vnto his rule subdewd,
Through all this realme, the glorie of her sex,
Next Huddibras his realme did not encrease,
Mongst whom his realme he equally decreed
And twixt them shayrd his realme by equall lots:
To war on those, which him had of his realme bereau'd.
Thenceforth this Realme was into factions rent,
Of this sad Realme, cut into sundry shaires
Which for this Realme found many goodly layes,
Till he surrendred Realme and life to fate.
Then gan this Realme renewe her passed prime:
Long time in peace his Realme established,
That in the Realme ere long they stronger arre,
Happie this Realme, had it remained euer since.
Who, after Greekes did Priams realme destroy,
And ioyne in equall portion of thy realme:
All hidden crimes, through all that realme he sent,
In which he was that Realme for to redresse.
Ne ruld her Realmes with lawes, but pollicie,
And thine owne realmes in lond of Faery,
But realmes and rulers thou doest both confound,
Vntill that Locrine for his Realmes defence,
With which he wonts the Stygian realmes inuade,
And to your willes both royalties and Realmes
And so were realmes and nations run awry.
His soule descended downe into the Stygian reame.
Should reap the haruest, ere it ripened were;
And hop'd to reape the crop of all my care,
To enter in, and reape the dew reward:
And reape sweet pleasure of the wanton boy;
Who reapes the haruest sowen by his foe,
Reaping eternall glorie of his restlesse paines.
That of his loue he reapt the timely frute,
High reard their royall throne in Britane land,
Ne reard aboue the earth his flaming creast,
Thrise he her reard, and thrise she sunke againe,
But when I other knew, my selfe I boldly reard.
Had reard himselfe againe to cruell fight,
With many raunges reard along the wall;
They reard a most outrageous dreadfull yelling cry,
And streight they saw the raging surges reard
Shortly they reard out of her frosen swownd;
His double folded necke she reard vpright,
Till that vnweeldy burden she had reard,
He reard him vp, and loosd his yron bands,
And hauing her from Trompart lightly reard,
Her vp betwixt his rugged hands he reard,
And Troy againe out of her dust was reard,
Out of the ruddy East was fully reard,
As one that had out of a dreame bene reard,
Then ere his hand he reard, he ouerthrew
That headlesse tyrants tronke he reard from ground,
But then the feend her selfe more fiercely reard
And paynd himselfe with busie care to reare
Therewith his heauie hand he high gan reare,
At them he gan to reare his bristles strong,
He found the meanes that Prisoner vp to reare;
As carefull Nourse her child from falling oft does reare.
But early ere the morrow next gan reare
From loathed soile he can him lightly reare,
And deadly woundes could heale, and reare againe
Of aged Tithone gan her selfe to reare,
When now he saw himselfe so freshly reare,
Therewith her dim eie-lids she vp gan reare,
Such and such euill God on Guyon reare,
An heauie load himselfe did lightly reare,
In widest Ocean she her throne does reare,
And crying Mercy lowd, his pitious hands gan reare.
As ghastly bug their haire on end does reare:
That might him moue to wrath, and indignation reare.
Her merry fit she freshly gan to reare,
He sent to Germanie, straunge aid to reare,
Vnweeting, what such horrour straunge did reare.
His deawy face out of the sea doth reare:
And shewd him many sights, that courage cold could reare.
Which by that new rencounter he should reare:
That none of them himselfe could reare againe;
Vntill that brasen wall they vp doe reare:
Then Griffyth Conan also shall vp reare
And all the conquests, which them high did reare,
Least his too haughtie hardines might reare
That their broad flaggie finnes no fome did reare,
Whiles they the corse into her wagon reare,
O Titan, haste to reare thy ioyous waine:
Lay hid: thereof she countlesse summes did reare,
That creeping close, amongst the hiues to reare
Then she, as morrow fresh, her selfe did reare
Would afterwards afresh the sleeping euill reare.
They vp againe them selues can lightly reare,
Fro me the honour of that game did reare;
And as his hand he vp againe did reare,
Which yeelded, they their beuers vp did reare,
He could outlearne, he them from ground did reare:
The shield it droue, and did the couering reare:
With that his murdrous mace he vp did reare,
And by the lilly hand her labour'd vp to reare.
And forced him, maulgre, it vp to reare.
That as his head he gan a litle reare
For wight, against his powre them selues to reare:
Vppon one side, and from his rootes doth reare.
And raging flames, that many foes shall reare,
And Ventailes reare, each other to behold.
That had he chaunced not his shield to reare,
Of all those crimes, that he gainst her doth reare,
And clasping twixt his armes, her vp did reare
He all his forces streight to him did reare,
No shame to stoupe, ones head more high to reare,
The whiles the cursed felon high did reare
But by what meanes did they at first it reare,
For little bootes against him hand to reare.
For since the day that armes I first did reare,
Gan reare her eyes as to the chearefull light,
Into his wounds, him vp thereon did reare,
Gan him recomfort, and from ground to reare.
Gainst errant Knights and Ladies thou dost reare,
Who was not able vp him selfe to reare,
The knight her lightly reared vp againe,
But he her quickly reared vp againe:
Or as a Castle reared high and round,
Approching nigh, he reared high afore
At his commaund, and reared him vp light
Till that young Squire him reared from below;
That vp his head he reared easily,
Soone as he heard, himself he reared light from ground.
They reared him on horsebacke, and vpstayd,
There reared was a castle faire and strong,
High reared mounts, the lands about to vew;
The roofe vp high was reared from the ground,
But ere they reared hand, the Amazone
The which this Gyant reared first on hie,
He reared her vp from the bloudie ground,
He could not rearen vp againe so light,
and reareth out of sownd.
And rearing fiercely their vpstarting crests,
Of which full proud, himselfe vp rearing hye,
Tho rearing vp his former feete on hight,
The eye of reason was with rage yblent,
Flesh may empaire (quoth he) but reason can repaire.
His goodly reason, and well guided speach
Those creeping flames by reason to subdew,
Whose hastie hand so farre from reason strayd,
His race with reason, and with words his will,
Robs reason of her due regalitie
With goodly reason, and thus faire bespake;
He hearkned to his reason, and the childe
Aboue the reason of her youthly yeares:
And reason with foole-hardize ouer ran;
When they would striue dew reason to exceed;
Whilst reason blent through passion, nought descride,
More rype vs reason lent to chose our Peares,
Gainst fort of Reason, it to ouerthrow:
Yet with strong reason maistred passion fraile,
So hauing him with reason pacifide,
May be, that better reason will asswage
Withouten reason or regard. Well knew
So that no time, nor reason could arize,
His goodly reason, and graue personage,
By reason that the Captaines on her side,
Against the fort of reason euermore
His wrathfull will with reason to asswage,
Ah, but if reason faire might you perswade,
For which no reason can find remedy.
(Said she) and though no reason may apply
For who with reason can you aye reproue,
But if thou may with reason yet represse
With reason dew the passion to subdew,
But reason teacheth that the fruitfull seades
So strong is passion, that no reason heares.
When they the reason of his words had hard,
That by no reason it might be reuerst,
But I with better reason him auiz'd,
With bowed backe, by reason of the lode,
Ne euer any asketh reason why.
That then all rule and reason they withstand,
Not fit mongst men, that doe with reason mell,
By reason of the streight, and rocks among,
Ripe yeares of reason, my right to maintaine.
To spare her Knight, and rest with reason pacifyde.
By reason that her knight was wounded sore.
T'expresse his passions, which his reason did empeach.
Therefore inclyning to his goodly reason,
Abusde, against all reason and all law,
Both of his words, which he with reason red;
And in his mind with better reason cast,
And robd of reason, towards her him bore,
Some fit for reasonable soules t'indew,
Of reasons rule, to see this recreant knight,
His partes to reasons rule obedient,
His wonder farre exceeded reasons reach,
Then reasons reach, and oft hath wonders donne.
With sting of lust, that reasons eye did blind,
And with her prayers reasons to restraine
And that for reasons speciall priuitie:
Ne Iudges powre, ne reasons rule mote them restraine.
And lawlesse lust to rule with reasons lore;
Ne within reasons rule, her madding mood containe.
And with sharpe reasons rang her such a pele,
That many high regards and reasons gainst her red.
And reasons brought, that no man could refute;
And follow'd them, in mind her to haue reau'd
He to him lept, in mind to reaue his life,
To reaue by strength the griped gage away:
Sith that false Traytour did my honour reaue?
I will him reaue of armes, the victors hire,
Whe[n] the wroth Western wind does reaue their locks;
To reaue her honor, which she more then life prefard.
Till I her find, and wreake on him that her did reaue.
Or reaue out of the hand, that did it hend.
Withouten cause, but onely her to reaue
Great treason to him meant, his life to reaue.
But like a ghastly Gelt, whose wits are reaued,
The liuing Lady, which from thee he reaued:
Rebeaten backe vpon him selfe againe,
Through proud ambition, against her rebeld,
But like a rebell stout I will him vse.
Had damn'd her sonnes, which gainst them did rebell,
Or did rebell gainst lawfull gouernment;
Against the Titans, that whylome rebelled
A prowd rebellious Vnicorne defies,
Ne henceforth be rebellious vnto loue,
And proud rebellious flesh to mortify.
Mote in them stirre vp old rebellious thought,
Yet did he murmure with rebellious sound,
And murdred cruelly by a rebellious Mayd.
For penaunce of my proud and hard rebellious hart.
The raging Buls rebellow through the wood,
That all the fields rebellowed againe;
And all the aire rebellowed againe.
Through an vnwary dart, which did rebound
That their report did farre away rebound,
That through the woods their Eccho did rebound.
The woods did nought but ecchoes vaine rebound;
But backe rebounding, left the forckhead keene;
That it rebounds against the lowly plaine,
From vnder that deepe Rocke most horribly rebounds.
Which through the wood loud bellowing, did rebownd,
That backe againe it did aloft rebownd,
And ran towards the far rebownded noyce,
Do meete together, each abacke rebowndes
In holy righteousnesse, without rebuke or blame.
Her to rebuke, for being loose and light:
For great rebuke it is, loue to despise,
Her sharpe rebuke full litle did esteeme;
If wrathfull wight, then fowle rebuke and shame
Ne euer for rebuke or blame of any balkt.
And sharpe rebuke, for being ouer bold;
For the rebuke, which she sustain'd that day,
Abasht at his rebuke, that bit her neare,
Beheld, they her rebuked and vpbrayded sore.
But them the Priest rebuking, did aduize
He much rebukt those wandring eyes of his,
Do backe rebut, and each to other yeeldeth land.
Their sharpe assault right boldly did rebut,
Perforce rebutted backe. The weapon bright
Coyly rebutted his embracement light;
That both rebutted, tumble on the plaine:
Rebutting him, which in the midst did ryde,
Whom by no meanes thou canst recall againe;
Who with entire affection him receau'd,
Me list not (said the Elfin knight) receaue
Did commun breath and nouriture receaue?
And with such vncouth welcome did receaue
Made drunke with drugs of deare voluptuous receipt.
Receiu'd, as knight of so much worth became,
Where they are well receiu'd, and made to spoile
He gan to hope, of men to be receiu'd
She in receiu'd; but Atin by no way
And she receiu'd againe to bed and bord,
That he thereby receiu'd no hurt at all,
And him receiu'd againe to former fauours state.
And had receiu'd their follies worthy hire,
And body haue receiu'd a mortall wound,
He did receiue, whiles flashing fire about him shone.
But doe vouchsafe now to receiue reliefe,
To bind their doers, to receiue their meede?
Him to receiue with entertainment meete.
More eath was new impression to receiue,
Could take no rest, ne would receiue reliefe,
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
As a bad Nurse, which fayning to receiue
Some place shall vs receiue, and harbour yield;
For to receiue the doome of her decay.
The gate soone opened to receiue him in,
That first receiued Christianitie,
Receiued is to grace and new accord,
Through grieuaunce of his late receiued wound,
Of faire Poeana I receiued was,
But when of him no aunswere she receiued,
Where soone arriuing they receiued were
There she receiued was in goodly wize
Receiued had, and prayd to pitty his ill plight.
He of the Prince his life receiued late,
As if he neuer had receiued fall;
But answer none receiues: the darknes him does shrowd.
There fairely them receiues a gentle Squire,
Which she receiuing with meete thankefulnesse,
Whom she receiuing by the lilly hand,
Both doing and receiuing curtesies,
Till that, as comes by course, I doe recite,
I no whit reck, ne you the like need to reherce.
What doe I recke, sith that he dyde entire?
That like on earth no where I recken may:
Yet when she reckned them, still drawing neare,
Or ought more hard, then thinke to reckon right.
Vaine man (said she) that wouldest be reckoned
And in her fauour high be reckoned,
Till Arthur all that reckoning did defray;
That he of little things made reckoning light,
They fall too short of our fraile reckonings,
Ne reckt of Ladies Loue, did stay behind,
Ne reckt she, who her meaning did mistrust;
So shall the Briton bloud their crowne againe reclame.
Their purpost flight, free from all mens reclame;
Ne from his currish will awhit reclame.
And willed him for to reclayme with speed
